guide.title: Gentoo Documentation Project Formatting Guide
guide.abstract: This guide will cover the formatting basics for GDP documentation.

body.p: The purpose of this guide is to provide some examples of proper formatting for GDP (Gentoo Documentation Project) documentation. Before reading this guide, it is expected that you have read both the XML Guide and the Documentation Policy.

Since the main goal of the GDP is to create clear and concise documentation, it comes as no big surprise that our documentation follows a strict set of formatting guidelines. Not only do these guidelines ensure that our documentation is structurally clear, but they keep the documentation portable, enabling the documentation to be migrated with website changes and transformed into a number of different formats, such as Postscript or PDF.

The layout of a basic GDP guide is very hierarchial. The overall guide is contained in a guide tag, with main topics in chapter tags, and sub topics in section tags contained within the greater chapter tags. Basically, the form of a document follows much that of a college type outline:

section.title: Using the right tags in the right place

body.p: The Gentoo/ GDP XML format has a ton of tags that do many nifty things. The problem is, there are so many tags that do similar tasks, it is hard to know which tags should be used where. For starters, the i tags are used to highlight text for emphasis. For example: Make sure you never do rm -rf /. The e tag on the other hand, italizes words for a less enhancing effect. For example: It is highly recommended to remove Windows in great times of frustration. As far as emphasizing commands, the c tag is the correct tag to use. For example: Please run etc-update after each emerge -u world, or suffer the wrath of the bug-wranglers.

XML documentation is still coding to some degree. So please, please, indent correctly. If you are unsure on how to properly indent, please check out some of the existing guides in CVS. No more to say here, moving on.
